At the expiration of his city-praetorship, he obtained by lot, not without some suspicion, as Cicero hints, of fraudulent practices, the praetorship of Sicily, the richest and most flourishing of the Roman pro- vinceS, Rc. 73. Unfortunately for the province, his tenure of this office was extended for eighteen months beyond the legal year, as his destined successor, Q. Arrius, was detained in Italy by thc servile war.

8. Cicero had been quaestor of Lilybaeum in Rc. 75, and had gained the goodwill and confidence of the Sicilians by the strict integrity and rigid impartiality of his administration. It was to him therefore that they now turned in their distreSS, begging him to undertake the prosecution of Verres, and seek redress
